svg.text: Would you teach me how to play the guitar?
No! (Nothing is preventing me from teaching you, but I am unwilling to do so.).
There are regional differences in how all languages are spoken.
In Chinese, one common variation is the addition of an “r” sound
to the ends of some words. This even has its own name:
But for many Chinese people, especially those in the north, it is
(yìdiǎnr), which sounds like yìdiǎr, with the
last syllable said in a nasal way. What are some regional accents
([yì]diǎnr) is often used before a noun, and it means to “do a little bit of (that
in this phrase is usually optional.
You should go do a bit of homework.
我能吃一点儿这个菜吗？
Can I have a bit of this dish?
